channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description:
One of the wonderful things of being of a certain age is that I have wonderful nostalgic childhood memories of typewriters which renew my deep appreciation for having moved past that technology. https://t.co/4bI8foGDOP

Likewise with programming with punch cards, only more so. Much more so, because the Fun Thing about punchcards is that there was no backspace key or Witeout. Make a mistake and you have to retype the card (a line of code) from scratch.
item.source:markdown:
One of the wonderful things of being of a certain age is that I have wonderful nostalgic childhood memories of typewriters which renew my deep appreciation for having moved past that technology. https://t.co/4bI8foGDOP
Likewise with programming with punch cards, only more so. Much more so, because the Fun Thing about punchcards is that there was no backspace key or Witeout. Make a mistake and you have to retype the card (a line of code) from scratch.

item.description:
I read the chapters on Pinchas and Mattot-Massei this Shabbos. https://t.co/wJaCba7ajG

For Pinchas, Rabbi Feigelson looks at the Avodat Yisrael by the Maggid of Kozhnitz; for M-M the Izhbitzer.

Coming in time for Simchat Torah from @BenYehudaPress https://t.co/tbpaTPbgnT

Rabbi Feigelson leads @theIJSS_ and this work uses Chassidic teachings ‚Äî included in the original along with a translation ‚Äî to discuss contemporary issues.

For Pinchas, he starts by looking to R Jonathan Sacks to frame the distinction between unity and wholeness.
item.source:markdown:
I read the chapters on Pinchas and Mattot-Massei this Shabbos. https://t.co/wJaCba7ajG
For Pinchas, Rabbi Feigelson looks at the Avodat Yisrael by the Maggid of Kozhnitz; for M-M the Izhbitzer.
Coming in time for Simchat Torah from @BenYehudaPress https://t.co/tbpaTPbgnT
Rabbi Feigelson leads @theIJSS_ and this work uses Chassidic teachings ‚Äî included in the original along with a translation ‚Äî to discuss contemporary issues.
For Pinchas, he starts by looking to R Jonathan Sacks to frame the distinction between unity and wholeness.

item.description:
@trekonomics And the Popular Front was less popular than the average cold front is cold.

item.description:
@trekonomics One possible tell of cryotofascist religious apologetics/propaganda is the cargo cult usage of terms such as ‚Äúprogress‚Äù and ‚ÄúChristianity‚Äù without actually engaging with the facts and ideas they‚Äôre ostensibly pointing to.

@trekonomics Is he calling for a return of sumptuary laws? A ban on interest bearing loans? Disenfranchising Jews? just to take three historical examples of an actual Christian legal order.
item.source:markdown:

item.description: @smith_randallk @scalzi @Sandhilldiary Yes. My friend graduated Yale in '86. She used the phrase sarcastically, with the clear Communist Party reference, and it was criticizing the far left from a standard liberal perspective.
item.source:markdown: @smith_randallk @scalzi @Sandhilldiary Yes. My friend graduated Yale in '86. She used the phrase sarcastically, with the clear Communist Party reference, and it was criticizing the far left from a standard liberal perspective.

item.description:
Here's the thing: the values of personal freedom and individual choice that let me decide to wear a yarmulke as an eighth grader in a public school are the same one that require me to accept people's determination of their gender and marriage partner. https://t.co/FFsxRfW7Gp

Ben is basically arguing that this time, Christian supremacy is good for the Jews. Given how little they care for the lives of Christian women with ectopic pregnancy, I have my doubts.
item.source:markdown:
Here's the thing: the values of personal freedom and individual choice that let me decide to wear a yarmulke as an eighth grader in a public school are the same one that require me to accept people's determination of their gender and marriage partner. https://t.co/FFsxRfW7Gp
Ben is basically arguing that *this* time, Christian supremacy is good for the Jews. Given how little they care for the lives of *Christian* women with ectopic pregnancy, I have my doubts.

item.description: @scalzi @Sandhilldiary I'm so old, that I remember learning the phrase "politically correct" from someone who had picked it up as a recent undergrad, before it made its breakout into the rightwing mediasphere. That is to say, during the Reagan Administration.
item.source:markdown: @scalzi @Sandhilldiary I'm so old, that I remember learning the phrase "politically correct" from someone who had picked it up as a recent undergrad, *before* it made its breakout into the rightwing mediasphere. That is to say, during the Reagan Administration.
